newsitem.title: USA: U.S. farmers holding out for $3.50 corn, $7.50 soy.
newsitem.headline: U.S. farmers holding out for $3.50 corn, $7.50 soy.

text.p: Slow farmer corn and soybean selling in the U.S. Midwest have held cash basis levels firm and farmers are not likely to sell unless prices rebound at least $0.80 per bushel, grain analysts said.
"I think farmers are going to be looking for $3.50 on corn and closer to $7.50 or $8.00 on beans," said Joe Miller, market analyst with the Indiana Farm Bureau.
"We may not get to those prices but I think that's what they're going to be waiting for," Miller added.
Chicago Board of Trade corn and soybean futures prices have fallen more than $1.00 per bushel since July, prompting many farmers to store their crops in hopes of a recovery.
And country elevators have responded by holding cash basis bids at historically high levels.
While flat prices are lower than they were a year ago when concerns of a small crop drove prices sharply higher, basis bids at several country locations were sharply higher.
"I think the basis level is a fair measurement of the farmer's perception of the price," said Dave Armstrong, grain analyst with The Chicago Corporation.
"This year, farmers believe this is too low a price," Armstrong said.
Bids for delivery at Clinton, Iowa, were at 15 cents over CBOT December futures on Monday. December futures closed at $2.80-1/4 per bushel on Friday.
That same location was quoting bids at 11 cents under the December on Oct. 23, 1995 while December futures stood at $3.35 per bushel.
"That is a very large difference in basis levels for corn," Armstrong added. "Five cents is noticeable and 10 cents is large."

One central Illinois river elevator noted basis levels at this time of year typically range from five to 10 cents a bushel under CBOT December. On Monday, bids stood at 10-1/2 cents over the December.
A merchandiser there said farmers would likely sell at least a portion of their corn crops if prices rallied 20 cents per bushel.
"I've got offers here that are less than ($3.50 per bushel)," said the grain dealer who declined to be named. "Farmers would move some grain at the $3.00 level."
Soybeans would likely move at $7.00 per bushel, he added.
